headline.main: Did Any Good Come of Watergate?

docs.abstract: Watergate inspired calls for regulating political fund-raising, ethical codes and aggressive journalism, as well as scorn for secrecy and surveillance. Have those notions survived?
docs.snippet: Watergate inspired calls for regulating political fund-raising, ethical codes and aggressive journalism, as well as scorn for secrecy and surveillance. Have those notions survived?

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists are experimenting with a new procedure to reduce high blood pressure in patients who do not respond to medication.

headline.seo: Experimental Surgery Targets Stubbornly High Blood Pressure
headline.main: To Cut Blood Pressure, Nerves Get a Jolt
headline.print_headline: To Cut Blood Pressure, Nerves Get a Jolt

docs.abstract: Doctors are experimenting with a new electrical procedure to treat high blood pressure in patients who are resistant to standard treatments; procedure involves pulses of radio-frequency energy that are delivered to the arteries leading to a patient's kidney.
docs.snippet: Scientists are experimenting with a new procedure to reduce high blood pressure in patients who do not respond to medication.

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeing too much of ourselves in other animals might not be the problem we think it is. Underappreciating our own animal natures may be the greater limitation.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by cardiology Prof Barbara Natterson-Horowitz and author Kathryn Bowers, adapted from their book Zoobiquity: What Animals Can Teach Us About Health and the Science of Healing, highlights the commonalities between humans and other animals; outlines what these commonalities, which they have observed by working with veterinarians, could mean for the treatment of human illnesses.
docs.snippet: Seeing too much of ourselves in other animals might not be the problem we think it is. Underappreciating our own animal natures may be the greater limitation.

byline.original: By BARBARA NATTERSON-HOROWITZ and KATHRYN BOWERS

docs.lead_paragraph: At high schools across the United States, pressure over grades and competition for college admissions are encouraging students to abuse stimulants.

headline.seo: Seeking Academic Edge, Teenagers Abuse Stimulants
headline.main: Risky Rise of the Good-Grade Pill
headline.print_headline: Risky Rise of the Good-Grade Pill

docs.abstract: Pressure over grades and competition for college admissions are encouraging many American high school students to abuse prescription stimulants; highly addictive medicines are intended to calm people with ADHD, but students without the disorder say they provide a jolt of energy and focus that enables them to study for longer than they otherwise could.
docs.snippet: At high schools across the United States, pressure over grades and competition for college admissions are encouraging students to abuse stimulants.

docs.lead_paragraph: FIFA’s chief medical officer has revealed that 39 percent of all players at the 2010 World Cup took painkillers before every game.

headline.main: Unrelenting Pressure to Mask the Pain
headline.print_headline: Unrelenting Pressure to Mask the Pain

docs.snippet: FIFA’s chief medical officer has revealed that 39 percent of all players at the 2010 World Cup took painkillers before every game.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite striking in a region receiving considerable development aid, nodding disease has confused doctors in Uganda, where it has killed more than 200 children since January.

headline.seo: Ugandans Turn to Healers for Mystery Disease
headline.main: Desperate Ugandans Seek Makeshift Healers as Mysterious Illness Strikes Young
headline.print_headline: Desperate Ugandans Seek Makeshift Healers as Mysterious Illness Strikes Young

docs.abstract: People of Ojuru, Uganda, are turning to traditional healers for nodding disease, a mysterious ailment that has stalked the brains and nervous systems of thousands of children in this part of Africa; debilitating disease stunts growth, causes mental retardation and sets off sudden seizures; no one knows what causes it, and it appears to attack only children; since January, more than 200 Ugandan children have died from the disease.
docs.snippet: Despite striking in a region receiving considerable development aid, nodding disease has confused doctors in Uganda, where it has killed more than 200 children since January.

docs.abstract: Ron Gould says he won't back down from liberals at The Times, just like he won't back down from liberals in Washington.
docs.snippet: Ron Gould says he won't back down from liberals at The Times, just like he won't back down from liberals in Washington.
